adjectives.description: little (comparative less or lesser or littler, superlative least or littlest)

examples: Did he tell you any embarrassing stories about when she was little?
That's the biggest little boy I've ever seen.

definitionGroups.group: (often capitalized) Used with the name of a place, especially of a country or its capital, to denote a neighborhood whose residents or storekeepers are from that place.

entries.meaning: (derogatory) To imply that the inhabitants of the place have an insular attitude and are hostile to those they perceive as foreign.
(of an industry or other field, or institution(s) therein, often capitalized) Operating on a small scale.
examples: Little Steel (smaller steel companies, as contrasted with Big Steel)
Little Science (science performed by individuals or small teams, as contrasted with Big Science)
I feel better after my little sleep.

entries.meaning: Small in extent of views or sympathies; narrow; shallow; contracted; mean; illiberal; ungenerous.
examples: The long-necked geese of the world that are ever hissing dispraise, / Because their natures are little.

adverbs.description: little (comparative less or lesser, superlative least)

examples: This is a little known fact.â€ƒ She spoke little and listened less.
We slept very little last night.
I was speaking ill of Fred; little did I know that he was right behind me, listening in.

entries.meaning: (chiefly uncountable or in the singular) A small amount.
examples: Can I try a little of that sauce?
Little did he do to make me comfortable.
If you want some cake, there's a little in the refrigerator
Many littles make a mickle. (Scottish proverb)

entries.meaning: (countable, informal) A child; particularly an infant.
(countable, university slang) A newly initiated member of a sorority, who is mentored by a big.
(countable, BDSM) The participant in ageplay who acts out the younger role.
(countable) One who has mentally age regressed to a childlike state.
